ch.lambdaj
Class Lambda

java.lang.Object
  ch.lambdaj.Lambda

public final class Lambda
extends Object

This class consists exclusively of static methods that allow to use all the core features of the lambdaj library.

Author:
Mario Fusco

aggregate(Object iterable, Aggregator<T> aggregator)

static
<T,A> T
aggregate(Object iterable, Aggregator<T> aggregator, A argument)
          For each item in the given iterable collects the value defined by the given argument and then aggregates them iterable using the given Aggregator.
static
<T,A> T
aggregateFrom(Iterable<T> iterable, Aggregator<A> aggregator)
          Returns a lambda function defined as:

aggregateFrom : (aggregator, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object to be aggregated.

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object to be aggregated.

Method Detail

on

public static <T> T on(Class<T> clazz)
Constructs a proxy object that mocks the given Class registering all the subsequent invocations on the object.

Parameters:
clazz - The class of the object to be mocked
Returns:
An object of the given class that register all the invocations made on it

argument

public static <T> Argument<T> argument(T argumentPlaceholder)
Returns the actual argument of the methods invocation sequence defined through the on(Class) method.

Parameters:
argumentPlaceholder - The placeholder for this argument created using the on(Class) method
Returns:
The actual argument of the methods invocation sequence defined through the on(Class) method

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(Iterable<? extends T> iterable)
Transforms a collection of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the collection with a single strong typed method call as in the following example: 
                List<Person> personInFamily = asList(new Person("Domenico"), new Person("Mario"), new Person("Irma"));
                forEach(personInFamily).setLastName("Fusco");
The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the iterable
Parameters:
iterable - The iterable to be transformed
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the iterable or null if the iterable is null or empty
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is null or empty

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Transforms a collection of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the collection with a single strong typed method call. The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the iterable
Parameters:
iterator - The iterator to be transformed
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the iterator or null if the iterator is null or empty
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is null or empty

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(Iterable<? extends T> iterable,
                            Class<T> clazz)
Transforms a collection of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the collection with a single strong typed method call as in the following example: 
                List<Person> personInFamily = asList(new Person("Domenico"), new Person("Mario"), new Person("Irma"));
                forEach(personInFamily, Person.class).setLastName("Fusco");
The given class represents the proxied by the returned object, so it should be a superclass of all the objects in the iterable. This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the iterable
Parameters:
iterable - The iterable to be transformed
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the iterable. If the given iterable is null or empty it returns an instance of T that actually proxies an empty Iterable of Ts

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(Iterator<? extends T> iterator,
                            Class<T> clazz)
Transforms an iterator of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the iterator with a single strong typed method call. The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the iterator
Parameters:
iterator - The iterator to be transformed
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the iterator or null if the iterator is null or empty
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterator is null or empty

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(T... array)
Transforms an array of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the array with a single strong typed method call.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the array
Parameters:
array - The array to be transformed
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the array

forEach

public static <T> T forEach(Class<T> clazz,
                            T... array)
Transforms an array of Ts in a single object having the same methods of a single instance of T. That allows to invoke a method on each T in the array with a single strong typed method call.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the items in the array
Parameters:
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
array - The array to be transformed
Returns:
An object that proxies all the item in the array

flatten

public static <T> List<T> flatten(Object iterable)
Flattens the given iterable by recursively descending through its nested Collections and create a flat List of all of the leaves. This method also works with Maps (by collecting their values) and arrays.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable to be flattened
Returns:
The flattened iterable

collect

public static <T> List<? extends T> collect(Object iterable)
Collects the items in the given iterable putting them in a List. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of which the items should be collected
Returns:
A List containing all the items collected from the give iterable
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is not an Iterable or a Map

collect

public static <T> List<T> collect(Object iterable,
                                  T argument)
For each item in the given iterable collects the value defined by the given argument and put them in a List. For example the following code: 
                List<Person> myFriends = asList(new Person("Biagio", 39), new Person("Luca", 29), new Person("Celestino", 29));
                List<Integer> ages = collect(meAndMyFriends, on(Person.class).getAge());
extracts the ages of all the Persons in the list and put them in a List of Integer.

Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of which the items should be collected
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A List containing all the items collected from the give iterable
Throws:
RuntimeException - if the iterable is not an Iterable or a Map

sort

public static <T> List<T> sort(Object iterable,
                               Object argument)
Sorts all the items in the given iterable on the respective values of the given argument. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be sorted
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A List with the same items of the given iterable sorted on the respective value of the given argument

sort

public static <T,A> List<T> sort(Object iterable,
                                 A argument,
                                 Comparator<A> comparator)
Sorts all the items in the given iterable on the respective values of the given argument comparing them with the given comparator. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be sorted
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
comparator - The comparator to determine the order of the list. A null value indicates that the elements' natural ordering should be used
Returns:
A List with the same items of the given iterable sorted on the respective value of the given argument

count

public static <T> Map<T,Integer> count(Object iterable)
Counts the number of occurrencies of the objects in the given iterable Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be counted
Returns:
A map having as values the number of occurrencies of the corresponding key in the given iterable

count

public static <A> Map<A,Integer> count(Object iterable,
                                       A argument)
Counts the number of occurrencies of the argument's value in the objects of the given iterable Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects' arguments to be counted
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A map having as values the number of occurrencies of the corresponding object's argument in the given iterable

filter

public static <T> List<T> filter(org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher,
                                 Iterable<T> iterable)
Filters all the objects in the given iterable that match the given hamcrest Matcher

Parameters:
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable
iterable - The iterable of objects to be filtered
Returns:
A sublist of the given iterable containing all the objects that match the given hamcrest Matcher

filter

public static <T> List<T> filter(org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher,
                                 T... array)
Filters all the objects in the given array that match the given hamcrest Matcher

Parameters:
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given array
array - The array of objects to be filtered
Returns:
A sublist of the given array containing all the objects that match the given hamcrest Matcher

select

public static <T> List<T> select(Iterator<T> iterator,
                                 org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher)
Selects all the objects in the given iterator that match the given hamcrest Matcher

Parameters:
iterator - The iterator of objects to be filtered
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable
Returns:
A sublist of the given iterable containing all the objects that match the given hamcrest Matcher

select

public static <T> List<T> select(Iterable<T> iterable,
                                 org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher)

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be filtered
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable
Returns:
A sublist of the given iterable containing all the objects that match the given hamcrest Matcher

select

public static <T> List<T> select(Object iterable,
                                 org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher)
Selects all the objects in the given iterable that match the given hamcrest Matcher Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be filtered
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable
Returns:
A sublist of the given iterable containing all the objects that match the given hamcrest Matcher

selectIterator

public static <T> Iterator<T> selectIterator(Object iterable,
                                             org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher)
Selects all the objects in the given iterable that match the given hamcrest Matcher Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable). Unlike the method select(Iterable, Matcher) this one doesn't build a new collection, and the selection is done while iterating the returned iterator.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be filtered
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable
Returns:
An iterator containing all the objects in the given iterable converted using the given Converter

selectUnique

public static <T> T selectUnique(Object iterable,
                                 org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher)
Selects the unique object in the given iterable that matches the given hamcrest Matcher Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be filtered
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable
Returns:
The only object in the given iterable that matches the given hamcrest Matcher or null if there is no such object
Throws:
NotUniqueItemException - if there is more than one object that matches the given hamcrest Matcher

                             org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher)

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects to be filtered
matcher - The hamcrest Matcher used to filter the given iterable

aggregate

public static <T> T aggregate(Object iterable,
                              Aggregator<T> aggregator)
Aggregates the items in the given iterable using the given Aggregator. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of numbers to be summed
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
Returns:
The result of the aggregation of all the items in the given iterable
Throws:
RuntimeException - if the iterable is not an Iterable

aggregate

public static <T,A> T aggregate(Object iterable,
                                Aggregator<T> aggregator,
                                A argument)
For each item in the given iterable collects the value defined by the given argument and then aggregates them iterable using the given Aggregator. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of numbers to be summed
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
The result of the aggregation of all the items in the given iterable
Throws:
RuntimeException - if the iterable is not an Iterable

aggregateFrom

public static <T,A> T aggregateFrom(Iterable<T> iterable,
                                    Aggregator<A> aggregator)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

aggregateFrom : (aggregator, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object to be aggregated. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be aggregated.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be aggregated.
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing an aggregation lambda function
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is null or empty

aggregateFrom

public static <T,A> T aggregateFrom(Iterable<T> iterable,
                                    Class<?> clazz,
                                    Aggregator<A> aggregator)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

aggregateFrom : (aggregator, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object to be aggregated. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be aggregated. This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be aggregated.
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
aggregator - The function that defines how the objects in this iterable have to be aggregated
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing an aggregation lambda function

sum

public static Number sum(Object iterable)
Sums the items in the given iterable of Numbers or the iterable itself if it actually is already a single number. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of numbers to be summed
Returns:
The sum of all the Number in the given iterable or the iterable itself if it actually is already a single number
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is not neither an Iterable nor a Number

sum

public static <T> T sum(Object iterable,
                        T argument)
Sums the property values of the items in the given iterable defined by the given argument. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of items containing the property of which the values have to be summed.
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
The sum of the property values extracted from all the items in the given iterable
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is not an Iterable

sumFrom

public static <T> T sumFrom(Iterable<T> iterable)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

sumFrom : (+, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => number) => number

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a number. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

int totalAge = sumFrom(persons).getAge();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be summed.
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a sum lambda function
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is null or empty

sumFrom

public static <T> T sumFrom(Iterable<T> iterable,
                            Class<?> clazz)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

sumFrom : (+, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => number) => number

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a number. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

int totalAge = sumFrom(persons, Person.class).getAge();

This overloaded version should be always used when it is not insured that the given iterable is null or empty.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be summed.
clazz - The class proxied by the returned object
Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a sum lambda function

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a number. int averageAge = avgFrom(persons).getAge();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Returns:
A proxy of the class of the first object in the iterable representing a sum lambda function

minFrom

public static <T> T minFrom(Iterable<T> iterable)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

minFrom : (min, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => object

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines how each item must be converted in the object of which a minimum value needs to be found. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be aggregated.

int minAge = maxFrom(persons).getAge();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of objects on which the minimum should be found
Returns:

IllegalArgumentException - if the iterable is null or empty

                             String separator)
Returns a lambda function defined as:

joinFrom : (concat, iterable) => lambda : (convert : object => object) => string

It is then possibly to curry this function by selecting the convert function that defines of each item must be converted in a String. This is done by invoking on that returned object the method that returns the values of the property to be summed as in the following example

String names = joinFrom(persons, " - ").getFirstName();

The actual class of T is inferred from the class of the first iterable's item, but you can specify a particular class by using the overloaded method.

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable of the objects to containing the property to be joined.
separator - The String used to separe the Strings produced by this lambda function
Returns:

join

public static String join(Object iterable)
Joins all the object in the given iterable by concatenating all their String representation. It invokes toString() an all the objects and concatening them using the default separator ", ". Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be joined
Returns:
The concatenation of the String representation of all the objects in the given iterable or an empty String if the iterable is null or empty

join

public static String join(Object iterable,
                          String separator)
Joins all the object in the given iterable by concatenating all their String representation. It invokes toString() an all the objects and concatening them using the given separator. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be joined
separator - The String used to separe the item's String representation
Returns:
The concatenation of the String representation of all the objects in the given iterable or an empty String if the iterable is null or empty

converter - The converter that specifies how each object in the iterable must be converted
Returns:
A list containing all the objects in the given iterable converted using the given Converter

                                          Converter<F,T> converter)

Returns:

                                          T argument)

public static <F,T> List<T> extract(Object iterable,
                                    T argument)

iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A list containing the argument's value extracted from the object in the given iterable

extractIterator

public static <F,T> Iterator<T> extractIterator(Object iterable,
                                                T argument)
Converts all the object in the iterable extracting the property defined by the given argument. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Unlike the method extract(Object, Object) this one doesn't build a new collection, and the extraction is done only when someone iterates over the returned iterator. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A list containing the argument's value extracted from the object in the given iterable

extractString

public static List<String> extractString(Object iterable)

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted in strings
Returns:
A list containing the String representation of the objects in the given iterable

extractProperty

public static <F,T> List<T> extractProperty(Object iterable,
                                            String propertyName)
Converts all the object in the iterable extracting the named property. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be converted
propertyName - The name of the item's property on which the item must have no duplicated value
Returns:
A list containing the property's value extracted from the object in the given iterable

map

public static <F,T> Map<T,F> map(Object iterable,
                                 Converter<F,T> converter)
Maps the objects in the given iterable on the value extracted using the given Converter. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be mapped
converter - The converter that specifies the key on which each object should be mapped
Returns:
A map having as keys the argument value extracted from the objects in the given iterable and as values the corresponding objects

index

public static <F,T> Map<T,F> index(Object iterable,
                                   T argument)
Indexes the objects in the given iterable based on the value of their argument. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be indexed
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A map having as keys the argument value extracted from the objects in the given iterable and as values the corresponding objects

project

public static <T> List<T> project(Object iterable,
                                  Class<T> targetClass,
                                  Object... arguments)
Converts the objects in the given iterable in objects of the given target Class. The objects are created by invoking its constructor passing to it the values taken from the object to be converted using the given arguments. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be projected
targetClass - The class in which the objects in the given iterable must be converted
arguments - The arguments of the objects to be converted that will be used to create the objects of the target class
Returns:
A list of map where each map is the result of the projection of an object in the iterable

project

public static <F> List<Map<String,Object>> project(Object iterable,
                                                   Converter<F,Map.Entry<String,Object>>... projectors)
Projects the objects in the given iterable by converting each of them in a set of key/value pairs. Actually it handles also Maps, Arrays and Iterator by collecting their values. Note that this method accepts an Object in order to be used in conjunction with the forEach(Iterable).

Parameters:
iterable - The iterable containing the objects to be projected
projectors - The converters that define how each object should be projected
Returns:
A list of map where each map is the result of the projection of an object in the iterable

as

public static <F> Converter<F,Map.Entry<String,Object>> as(Object argument)
Creates a converter that projects the value of the argument of an object using as alias the argument property name as defined by Argument.getInkvokedPropertyName()

Parameters:
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A converter that can be used as projector in the project(Object, Converter[]) method

as

public static <F> Converter<F,Map.Entry<String,Object>> as(String alias,
                                                           Object argument)
Creates a converter that projects the value of the argument of an object using as the given alias

Parameters:
alias - The key on which the argument value is paired
argument - An argument defined using the on(Class) method
Returns:
A converter that can be used as projector in the project(Object, Converter[]) method

having

public static <T> HasArgumentWithValue<T,Boolean> having(Boolean argument)
Creates an hamcrest matcher that is evalued to true accordingly to the value of the passed argument

Parameters:
argument - The boolean argument defined using the on(Class) method that has to be matched
Returns:
The hamcrest matcher that is evalued to true accordingly to the value of the passed argument

having

public static <T,A> HasArgumentWithValue<T,A> having(A argument,
                                                     org.hamcrest.Matcher<?> matcher)
Creates an hamcrest matcher that is evalued to true if the value of the given argument satisfies the condition defined by the passed matcher.

Parameters:
argument - The argument defined using the on(Class) method that has to be matched
matcher - The matcher against which the value of the given argument has to be compared
Returns:
The hamcrest matcher that is evalued to true if the value of the passed argument matches the given matcher

by

public static <T> ArgumentGroupCondition<T> by(T argument)
Creates a GroupCondition that allows to group items based on the value they have on a given argument

Parameters:
argument - The argument defined using the on(Class) method on which the items have to be grouped
Returns:
A GroupCondition that can be used to group items through the Groups.group(Iterable, ch.lambdaj.group.GroupCondition[]) method

group

public static <T> Group<T> group(Iterable<T> iterable,
                                 Collection<? extends GroupCondition<?>> conditions)
Organizes the given list of items in (hierarchy of) groups based on the given grouping conditions

Parameters:
iterable - The items to be grouped
conditions - The conditions that define how the items have to be grouped
Returns:
The items grouped by the given conditions

group

public static <T> Group<T> group(Iterable<T> iterable,
                                 String... groupers)
Organizes the given list of items in (hierarchy of) groups based on the values they have on the named JavaBean proprties

Parameters:
iterable - The items to be grouped
groupers - The names of the properties on which the items have to be grouped
Returns:
The items grouped on the values of their JavaBean properties

group

public static <T> Group<T> group(Iterable<T> iterable,
                                 GroupCondition<?>... conditions)
Organizes the given list of items in (hierarchy of) groups based on the given grouping conditions

Parameters:
iterable - The items to be grouped
conditions - The conditions that define how the items have to be grouped
Returns:
The items grouped by the given conditions

of

public static <T> T of(T closed)
Binds an object to the active closure that is the last one created in the current thread.

Parameters:
closed - The object that has to be bound to the active closure
Returns:
A proxy of the same class of the passed object used to register all the invocation on the closed object

of

public static <T> T of(Class<T> closedClass)
Binds a free variable of the given class to the active closure that is the last one created in the current thread.

Parameters:
closedClass - The type of the free variable to be bound to the active closure
Returns:
A proxy of the same class of the passed class used to register all the invocation on the closed object

of

public static <T> T of(T closed,
                       Class<T> closedClass)
Binds an object to the active closure that is the last one created in the current thread.

Parameters:
closed - The object that has to be bound to the active closure
closedClass - The actual class of the proxied object
Returns:
An instance of the closedClass that is actually a proxy used to register all the invocation on the closed object

var

public static <T> T var(Class<T> clazz)
Defines a free variable of the given Class for the currently active closure

Parameters:
clazz - The Class of the new argument
Returns:
A placeholder that represent a free closure variable of the given Class

closure

public static Closure closure()
Creates a generic (not typed) closure and binds it to the current thread

Returns:
The newly created closure

closure

public static <A> Closure1<A> closure(Class<A> type1)
Creates a closure with a single free variable and binds it to the current thread

Parameters:
type1 - The type of the free parameter of the newly created closure
Returns:
The newly created closure

closure

public static <A,B> Closure2<A,B> closure(Class<A> type1,
                                          Class<B> type2)
Creates a closure with two free variables and binds it to the current thread

Parameters:
type1 - The type of the first free variable of the newly created closure
type2 - The type of the second free variable of the newly created closure
Returns:
The newly created closure

closure

public static <A,B,C> Closure3<A,B,C> closure(Class<A> type1,
                                              Class<B> type2,
                                              Class<C> type3)
Creates a closure with three free variables and binds it to the current thread

Parameters:
type1 - The type of the first free variable of the newly created closure
type2 - The type of the second free variable of the newly created closure
type3 - The type of the third free variable of the newly created closure
Returns:
The newly created closure

closure

public static <A,B,C,D> Closure4<A,B,C,D> closure(Class<A> type1,
                                                  Class<B> type2,
                                                  Class<C> type3,
                                                  Class<D> type4)
Creates a closure with four free variables and binds it to the current thread

Parameters:
type1 - The type of the first free variable of the newly created closure
type2 - The type of the second free variable of the newly created closure
type3 - The type of the third free variable of the newly created closure
type4 - The type of the fourth free variable of the newly created closure
Returns:
The newly created closure

delayedClosure

public static <T> ClosureResult<T> delayedClosure(DelayedClosure<T> delayedClosure)
Returns the result of the invocation of the method that uses the given delayed closure

Parameters:
delayedClosure - The closure defined through the DelayedClosure syntax
Returns:
The result of the invocation of the method that uses the given delayed closure
